RE: License#: CB280200990
Dear Ms. Harding:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
January 26, 2023. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:

R 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) The personnel record shall contain:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after
the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation shall be conducted each year.
Six of ten personnel files reviewed did not contain written evaluations as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/1/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/10/2022
R 400.12324 Reevaluation
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15 calendar
days before the expiration date of the foster home license.
One of three open foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the
licensing recommendation was made to the department at least 15 calendar days
before the expiration date of the foster home license.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time is
required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
One of four special investigations reviewed were not completed within 45 calendar
days and did not contain documentation the foster parent was notified of the need for
an extension.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an agency
shall complete a written report.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not have a report completed within 15
days of the conclusion of the evaluation.

R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an agency
shall complete a written report that includes all of the following
information:
(e) Findings of facts, based upon the evaluation.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not contain accurate findings of fact
based on the information gathered as the interviews were not detailed.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of the
child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
1 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-h of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days.
Four of six foster care files reviewed (4 of 22 service plans) did not have the Updated
Service Plan/Initial Service Plan completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/1/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/10/2022

R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and the foster parent in the foster parent’s home at
least once every month.
Two of six open foster care files reviewed did not have monthly visitation with the
worker and child in the foster placement as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/15/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/11/2021
2/1/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/10/2022
R 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the minimum supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service worker
and the youth in independent living at least once each
month at a youth’s place of residence.
One of one open independent living files reviewed did not have monthly visitation with
the worker and youth in the youth’s residence as required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 723 Educational services
Individualized Education Plan (IEP)
All educational information and related tasks, activities, and
contacts must be documented within the social work contacts,
case service plans, placement, and the education section of
MiSACWIS.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have the education section of MISACWIS
completed to reflect the youth’s IEP.

FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport must
be provided within two weeks of the child's placement date to the
following:
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management record.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child
is newly referred to and accepted for treatment and/or
services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment while
the foster care case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth age 16
and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults age
18 and older).
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.

Four of six open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/1/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/10/2022
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
Six of six foster care files and one of one independent living files reviewed did not
have supervisory approval of the case service plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/1/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/10/2022
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Five of six foster care files and one of one independent living files reviewed (14 of 22
service plans) did not contain all of the required signatures on the parent agency
treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/15/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/11/2021
2/1/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/10/2022
FOM 722-06H Quality visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been found
to produce positive outcomes for children in foster care. A quality
visit is defined as one in which the caseworker:
• Can meet with each child individually, without the presence of
other individuals, to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions as well as discuss the current placement.
• Views the child's bedroom and sleeping arrangements.
• Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for infants
under 12 months.

• Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental, mental
health and other needs and takes appropriate action or offers
services in response to the identified needs of each child.
• Shows interest in the child to build and establish rapport.
• Shares and explains the case plan, including the plan for
parenting time, visits with siblings and other relatives, and the
child's permanency plan, in a developmentally appropriate
way while allowing the child to ask questions and express
viewpoints.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation of a quality visit.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/1/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/10/2022
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include reunification,
placement in a residential setting, step-down from a residential or
hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or request for change in
foster home/relative placements.
Three of six foster care files and one of one independent living files reviewed did not
have FTM’s completed as required.

FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Six of six foster care files and one of one independent living files reviewed contained
FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven
business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/15/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/11/2021
2/1/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/10/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
• Include date emergency procedures were practiced in licensing reports.
• Upload letter sent to foster parents in CWLM when providing copy of special
investigation.
• Recommend developing tracking method to ensure performance evaluations
are completed timely.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The agency did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were 1 incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
A special evaluation initiated on 2/24/2022 regarding the allegations a licensed
relative caregiver overdosed on heroin in front of her biological child. The relative
was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency policy. Revocation of the
license took place in July 2022.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
A special evaluation initiated on 2/15/2022 regarding allegations a licensed relative
caregiver was utilizing corporal punishment as discipline. The relative was found to
be in violation of licensing rules and agency policy. A CAP was approved on
4/8/2022 and was completed successfully.

The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
interim inspection completed on 2/1/2022 with a corrective action plan approved on
2/10/2022. During the review the agency had thirteen violations. Eight citations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under review
the agency has struggled with significant staffing issues, specifically resignations
and performance issues.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting requirements during this
review period. Chief Administrator (CA) stated the previous CAP was effective and
the agency has made consistent efforts to improve expectations and follow through
with policy requirements. There are good systems in place, but the agency has
struggled with significant staffing issues, specifically resignations and performance
issues. CA also noted that issues within MISACWIS have also been a barrier. CA
stated the previous CAP was effective and the agency has made consistent efforts
to improve expectations and follow through with policy requirements.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff report feeling
supported by supervision and coworkers. Staff reported no concerns or areas of
need.
Financial Overview
In reviewing the financial information provided, there is no concerns noted.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were store securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified one safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert: During a home visit on 10/28/22 it was found the home had two smoke
alarms that were beeping due to having low battery.
Resolution: The agency verified new batteries were installed during a home visit on
11/1/2022. A photograph was submitted as verification the batteries were replaced
and the smoke alarms were working properly.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
